Reforming of methane over two-dimensional Mo2C-Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst Samira Shirvani Writing – original draft Validation Methodology Investigation Data curation Kevin J. Smith Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Methodology Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ Chemical and Biological Engineering Department, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, Canada Chemical and Biological Engineering Department, University of British Columbia Vancouver Canada Chemical and Biological Engineering Department, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, Canada ⁎ Corresponding author. The impact of two-dimensional Mo2C (2D-Mo2C) on the activity and stability of a Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst for the dry reforming of methane (DRM) is reported. 1.1 wt% 2D-Mo2C added to 13 wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3 increased activity by ∼40 %. Characterization results showed an interaction between 2D-Mo2C and Ni that resulted in the formation of a NixMoy bulk phase (XRD) and Ni-Mo-oxycarbide surface species (XPS). The presence of 2D-Mo2C also improved the stability of the catalyst compared to Ni/γ-Al2O3 by reducing coke deposition. H2 space-time-yields (STYs) were independent of CO2 partial pressure and were lower than the CO STYs. Power law kinetic models were consistent with a DRM reaction pathway via CH4 decomposition (MD) and the reverse Boudouard (RBD) reactions. Graphical Abstract Keywords Dry reforming Syngas Two-dimensional nanomaterials Molybdenum carbide Nickel Kinetics Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Dry reforming of methane (DRM, CH4 + CO2 ↔ 2CO + 2 H2) is an attractive reaction that mitigates two abundant green-house gases (CH4 and CO2) by converting them to a 1:1 (molar) mixture of H2 and CO (synthesis gas) [1]. However, thermodynamics requires high temperature (800 – 1000 °C) for significant reactant conversions [2] and at such conditions, several side reactions may also occur, including the reverse water-gas-shift reaction (RWGS, CO2 + H2 → CO + H2O), CH4 decomposition (MD, CH4 → C + 2 H2), and the reverse Boudouard reaction (RBD, CO2 + C → 2CO) [3]. Furthermore, at high temperature and atmospheric pressure in the absence of a strong oxidant, severe coke formation and sintering of the catalyst occurs [3]. Catalysts such as Ni, transition metal carbides and noble metals dispersed on high surface area supports such as Al2O3, SiO2, TiO2, CeO2, zeolites and activated carbon, have been reported for the reaction, with Ni/Al2O3 being the most promising due to its high activity and low cost [3–7]. However, Ni catalysts deactivate rapidly because of coke formation, while bimetallic catalysts have been shown to suppress carbon deposition and postpone catalyst deactivation [8] with Ni-Co one of the most stable bimetallic catalysts reported to date [8,9]. Addition of β-Mo2C to Ni/Al2O3 has also been shown to improve the activity and stability of the catalyst [10,11]. Diao et al. reported that addition of β-Mo2C to a Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst with a Ni/Mo molar ratio of 2/1, resulted in better dispersion of Ni nanoparticles which in turn resulted in improved activity and stability of the DRM catalyst when operated at 470 °C. The β-Mo2C also had high affinity for CO2 dissociation and facilitated charge deposition in the plasma-assisted DRM reaction [11]. Shi et al. also investigated the impact of β-Mo2C on Ni with Ni/Mo molar ratios of 1/3, 1/2, and 1/1 for the DRM reaction [12]. The results showed that a Ni/Mo ratio of 1/2 was optimum since at higher ratios the catalyst deactivated due to coke deposition and at lower ratios the catalyst deactivated due to oxidation to MoO2. Only at a ratio of 1/2 was there a balance between oxidation-recarburization which resulted in higher activity and stability of the catalyst [12]. Note also that the catalytic activity of β-Mo2C was quite negligible at the mentioned reaction conditions. In another study, Duan et al. synthesized a Ni-Mo2C/Al2O3 catalyst through a one-pot combustion process to obtain a structure which had high surface area and a strong interaction between metallic Ni and Mo2C, resulting in higher stability toward sintering and oxidation during the reaction. They proposed conversion of CH4 to C* and H2 over Ni0 with C* subsequently being converted to CO over adjacent Mo2C [13]. Recently, two-dimensional (2D) molybdenum carbide (2D-Mo2C) and two-dimensional vanadium carbide (2D-V2C), have also been successfully applied as catalysts for the DRM reaction [14,15]. 2D nanomaterials are defined as consisting of a few layers of atoms [16] and have proven beneficial when applied as electrocatalysts, photocatalysts, and thermocatalysts [17–19]. 2D molybdenum carbides, nitrides, and carbonitrides (MXenes) have also been reported as thermo-catalysts for the water-gas shift reaction [20], CH4 dehydroaromatization [21], furfural hydrogenation [22], CO2 hydrogenation [23], dibenzyltoluene hydrogenation/dehydrogenation [24], dry reforming of methane [14,15] and propane dehydrogenation [25]. The 2D-V2C catalyst used for DRM underwent an in situ transformation to produce a highly active V2O3-V8C7/m-V2CTx oxycarbide catalyst (where T is a surface termination group O–, OH–, and F– and x is the number of functional groups per unit formula) that also prevented coke formation [15]. Similarly, in a study of DRM by Kurlov et al., an oxycarbide Mo2COx/SiO2 surface species was formed over a 2D-Mo2C/SiO2 catalyst in the presence of CO2, which maximized metal utilization and provided a significant enhancement of the 2D-Mo2C activity [14]. Oxycarbide structures (NiMoOxCy), identified in previous studies following in-situ carburization of molybdenum oxide in the presence of Ni, also resulted in higher DRM activity and stability of the Ni catalyst [10]. Herein we report on the synthesis, properties, and activity of a bimetallic composite catalyst, consisting of 2D-Mo2C and Ni, supported on a high surface area γ-Al2O3, for DRM. We investigate the impact of different loadings of 2D-Mo2C on the performance of the Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, with the expectation of a higher activity and better stability in the presence of the 2D-Mo2C, because of the unique layered structure of the 2D nanomaterial. We also compare the impact of the 2D-Mo2C structure to the previously studied β-Mo2C, on the activity of the Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. Although Ni is active for DRM, especially at relatively low temperature, it has a high affinity for coke deposition; whereas, 2D-Mo2C is known to be resistant to high temperatures and coke formation [14]. With a higher Mo electronegativity compared to Ni, one would expect electron transfer from Ni to Mo which could increase the activity of the 2D-Mo2C. In addition, based on previous studies [10,14] the formation of oxycarbides in the presence of CO2 may further enhance the activity and stability of the catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials All chemicals including bulk molybdenum carbide (β-Mo2C, 99.5 %, 325 mesh), gallium (Ga, 99.99 %, trace metal basis), sodium fluoride (NaF, 99 %, ACS reagent), hydrochloric acid (HCl, 37 %, ACS reagent), nitric acid (HNO3, ACS reagent, 70 %), and nickel (II) nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2.6 H2O) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich and used as received. Al2O3 spheres (particle diameter of 1 mm and total acidity of 0.63 mmol/g) were purchased from Sasol. CH4 (99.97 %), CO2 (80 %)/Ar (20 %), H2, (99.999 %), Ar, (99.999 %), He, (99.999 %), and air (ultra-zero grade) were all purchased from Praxair. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis The 2D-Mo2C (MXene) used in this study was synthesized from Mo2Ga2C (MAX phase). To obtain the MAX phase, Ga and β-Mo2C (with a molar ratio of 10–1) were thoroughly mixed in a quartz boat while being heated at 70 °C to obtain a homogeneous grey mixture. The quartz boat was then placed inside a quartz tube in a horizontal electric furnace and heated to 850 °C at a heating rate of 10 °/min, while under vacuum (0.13 kPa). The sample was held at the final temperature for 48 h. The obtained MAX phase was first cooled to room temperature and placed in an HCl solution (37 %) for 48 h to remove the excess, unreacted Ga. Subsequently, the sample was repeatedly washed with deionized water (DI) and centrifuged until the decanted liquid reached a pH of 6. The sample was then dried overnight in air at 70 °C. To synthesize 2D-Mo2C, 1 g of the MAX phase with 1 g of NaF, 15 mL of HCl, and 15 mL of DI were mixed and placed inside an autoclave at 170 °C and autogenous pressure for 24 h. The resulting 2D-Mo2C recovered after reaction was repeatedly washed and centrifuged with DI until the decanted liquid reached a pH of 6. The sample was then washed and centrifuged with ethanol 3 times before drying in air at 70 °C overnight. To prepare the 2D-Mo2C-Ni/γ-Al2O3 composite catalysts with different loadings of 2D-Mo2C (0.7 – 2.6 wt%) and 13 wt% Ni, the required amount of Ni(NO3)2.6 H2O was dissolved in DI for 1 h under vigorous stirring before adding 2D-Mo2C to the solution. The resulting suspension was subjected to 1 h of sonication under an inert atmosphere in an ice bath to exfoliate the layers of 2D-Mo2C while preventing oxidation. The required amount of γ-Al2O3 was subsequently added to the suspension and mixed for 1 h before removal of the liquid by rotary evaporation at 60 °C and 10 kPa vacuum. A comparator catalyst of β-Mo2C-Ni/γ-Al2O3 was also synthesized via a conventional method. Accordingly, MoO3/γ-Al2O3 was synthesized by wet impregnation of γ-Al2O3 using ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate ((NH4)6Mo7O24) as a precursor. The impregnated γ-Al2O3 was dried overnight at 120 °C followed by calcination in air at 500 °C for 4 h. The obtained MoO3/γ-Al2O3 was then carburized using a mixture of 20 % CH4 and 80 % H2 by heating the solid from 25 to 300 °C at a heating rate of 10 °/min, followed by increasing the temperature to 750 °C at a heating rate of 1 °/min and holding at 750 °C for 2 h. Following cooling to room temperature the catalyst was passivated using a flow of 1 % O2 in N2 for 12 h. Ni was then added to the β-Mo2C/γ-Al2O3 catalyst by impregnation from a solution of Ni(NO3)2.6 H2O to obtain a Ni loading of 13 wt%, as before. The catalyst was dried overnight before further treatments. All catalysts were calcined in a 40 mL/min Ar flow at 750 °C for 2 h and then reduced in pure H2 at the same flow rate for another 2 h prior to characterization or activity testing. The catalysts are identified as X_2DMo-Ni/Al where X represents the mass loading of the 2D-Mo2C, with all catalysts having a nominal Ni content of ∼13 wt%. 2.3 Materials characterization Inductively coupled plasma mass spectroscopy (ICP-MS) was conducted using an Agilent 7700X instrument to measure the mass contents of Ni and Mo in all the catalysts. Prior to analysis, a known mass of the sample was dissolved in concentrated HCl and HNO3. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) of the catalysts was conducted on a Bruker D8-Advance X-ray diffractometer equipped with LynxEye detector using Cu Kα radiation in the 2θ range of 5° to 90°. The morphology of the samples was examined by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) using a Nova NanoSEM, FEI instrument. N2-physisorption analysis was done using a Micromeritics accelerated surface area and porosimetry unit (ASAP 2020) operated at –196 °C to obtain the Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) surface area and to measure pore volume and pore size based on the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Prior to the analysis the samples were degassed at 200 °C under vacuum for 4 h. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed using a Kratos analytical instrument to analyze the oxidation states of Mo and Ni and to determine the elemental composition of the catalyst surface. The reduced catalyst samples were transferred to the instrument under an Ar blanket to minimize oxidation by exposure to ambient air. Field emission transmission electron microscopy (FE-TEM) was conducted to analyze the morphology, element distributions and crystallographic information using energy dispersive X-ray analysis (EDX) and selected area electron diffraction (SEAD). Elemental concentrations reported from EDX analysis are based on average quantification from 5 different regions of each TEM image. Pulsed carbon monoxide (CO) uptake measurements were done using a Micromeritics AutoChem 2920 equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. Prior to analysis, the dried catalysts were calcined and reduced in-situ with Ar and H2, respectively, at 750 °C for 2 h in a gas flow rate of 40 mL(STP)/min. The sample was then cooled in an inert atmosphere of He to 35 °C before 0.5 mL CO pulses were injected into the He flow (50 mL(STP)/min). The process was repeated until no further CO uptake was observed [26]. The CO uptake is normalized per g of Ni and is used to determine catalyst turnover frequencies (TOFs). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was done with an SD-600 instrument manufactured by TA instruments. The temperature was first increased to 30 °C under 100 mL(STP)/min flow of N2 and kept at that condition for 30 min. Temperature was then increased to 1000 °C at a heating rate of 10 °/min under 100 mL(STP)/min flow of air and held at that temperature for another 30 min. 2.4 Dry reforming reaction The activity and selectivity of the catalysts for the dry reforming of methane was assessed using the experimental set-up shown in Fig. 1 S (Supporting Information). In a typical test, 400 mg of the dried catalyst was loaded into a quartz-lined stainless-steel reactor (quartz tube 13 mm ID x 15 mm OD x 600 mm long, ends fire polished with a porous frit located at 300 mm from one end) which was placed inside an electric furnace. The catalyst was calcined in a 40 mL/min Ar flow at 750 °C for 2 h and then reduced in pure H2 at the same flow rate for another 2 h. The reactor was then brought to the desired reaction temperature (650–850 °C) and the feed of CH4:CO2:Ar with a set volumetric ratio (1:1:0.25) was introduced at a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 13,500–90,000 mL(STP)/(h.gcat). Inlet flows were measured and controlled by Brooks mass flow controllers and the exit flow was measured using a bubble flow meter. Reactor pressure was monitored with two pressure gauges at the entrance and exit of the reactor (see Fig. S1). The ratio of CH4:CO2:Ar was held constant when screening catalysts but was varied for the kinetic study. Products from the reactor flowed through a condenser held in an ice-bath to remove produced water, before being analyzed every 10 minutes using an on-line Varian 3800 gas chromatograph (GC). The GC was equipped with two thermal conductivity detectors (TCDs) working with Ar and He as carrier gases and two packed columns (HayeSep R, 2 ft × 1/8 in, Mesh: 80 – 100 and HayeSep D, 10 ft × 1/8 in, Mesh: 100 – 120) and one flame ionization detector (FID) working with H2 as a carrier gas and a capillary column (CP-WAX 52 CB, 25 m × 0.32 mm). Blank tests were done in the absence of catalyst to confirm that there was insignificant thermal activity at the reaction conditions. The carbon balance was > 96 % in all experiments. The CH4 and CO2 conversions, H2 and CO space-time yields (STYs), H2/CO product molar ratio were calculated using the Eqs. 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 respectively. (1) X CH 4 ( % ) = ( 1 − F CH 4 , out F CH 4 , in ) × 100 (2) X CO 2 ( % ) = 1 − F CO 2 , out F CO 2 , in × 100 (3) STY H 2 μ mol s . g Ni = F TOTAL , out × y H 2 × 10 6 W Ni × 22.4 × 60 × 1000 (4) STY CO μ mol s . g Ni = F TOTAL , out × y CO × 10 6 W Ni × 22.4 × 60 × 1000 (5) H 2 CO = F H 2 , out F CO , out where X i is the conversion of reactant i (CH4 or CO2), F i is the flow rate of each of the components in mL(STP)/min, y i is the mole fraction of component i in the exit gas, STY i is the space-time yield of product i (CO or H2) in µmol/(s. gNi), and W Ni is the weight of Ni (based on the results from ICP-MS analysis) of each catalyst in g. The experimental data were not impacted by internal or external mass transfer and heat transfer limitations, as confirmed by calculation using the Mears and Weisz–Prater criteria (Eqs. 1S, 2S, and 3S). The results are shown in Table 1 S. Diagnostic experiments confirmed the absence of significant external mass transfer effects since the CH4 conversion rates remained constant as the feed gas flow rate was varied from 90 to 360 mL(STP)/min at constant gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 90,000 mL(STP)/(h. gCat) and temperature of 800 °C ( Fig. 2 S (a)). Similarly, internal diffusion effects were minimal since the CH4 conversion rates remained constant as the catalyst particle size was varied from 75 – 1165 µm (Fig. 2 S (b)). The repeatability of the data was also estimated by randomly re-synthesizing selected catalysts and performing repeat measurements of the catalyst activity and selectivity. Overall, the repeatability for H2 and CO STY was ± 2.4 % and ± 4.5 % of their mean values and for CH4 and CO2 conversions, the repeatability was ± 5.6 % and ± 3.7 % of their mean values, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization results The composition of the catalysts, as determined from the ICP-MS analysis is reported in Table 1. The Ni content was 12.67 ± 0.44 wt% for the Ni-containing catalysts with nominal Ni loading of 13 wt%, whereas the 2D-Mo2C content was 0.7, 1.1, and 2.6 wt% for the three catalysts promoted with 2D-Mo2C. The loading of β-Mo2C was 1.0 wt% for the comparator catalyst (β-Mo2C-Ni/γ-Al2O3). For simplicity, the catalyst identifiers shown in Table 1 are used throughout the manuscript. The successful synthesis of Mo2Ga2C (MAX phase) was confirmed by the XRPD and SEM of the as synthesized Mo2Ga2C, shown in Fig. 3 S. The XRPD pattern is similar to the reference pattern reported elsewhere [24] and the SEM image shows the hexagonal structure with close-packed layers, characteristic of the Mo2Ga2C [27]. The SEM images of the as synthesized 2D-Mo2C and β-Mo2C are shown in Fig. 1. The layered structure of 2D-Mo2C and the random bulk structure of β-Mo2C are quite distinct in the SEM images. The BET surface area of 2D-Mo2C was 2.5 m2/g which is consistent with previous reported values for other types of two-dimensional catalysts [28]. The XRPD patterns of the synthesized catalysts and γ-Al2O3 are shown in Fig. 2. The successful synthesis of 2D-Mo2C is confirmed by the appearance of the characteristic peak at ∼10° [20]. However, the peak was not apparent for the 1.1_2DMo-Ni/Al catalyst due to the high dispersion and low concentration of 2D-Mo2C, but it was present for the 2.6_2DMo-Ni/Al catalyst. There is a shift to lower angle once the 2D-Mo2C is loaded onto the γ-Al2O3 support [24] because of the sonication step done prior to supporting the 2D-Mo2C that results in exfoliation and increased spacing between the layers of 2D-Mo2C [14]. Peaks related to γ-Al2O3 and Ni were also identified. Due to the low concentration, peaks associated with β-Mo2C were not clear in the pattern of the 1.0_ βMo-Ni/Al catalyst. The emergence of a new peaks at ∼ 40.5°, 58.7°, and 73.8° of the XRPD patterns of the 1.1_2DMo-Ni/Al and 2.6_2DMo-Ni/Al catalysts, can be assigned to the presence of a NixMoy phase [29], resulting from a strong interaction between the Ni and Mo components of the catalyst [10,30]. The peaks were not observed in the βMo-Ni/Al XRD pattern indicating that a stronger interaction between Ni and Mo occurred with 2D-Mo2C compared to β-Mo2C. Table 1 also reports the textural properties of the catalysts, including the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area and the BJH pore volume and pore size. Upon loading Ni, 2D-Mo2C, and β-Mo2C, the surface area of the catalyst decreased compared to the surface area of the γ-Al2O3 support. The decrease was more severe upon the addition of Ni and β-Mo2C. The spaces between the layers of the 2D-Mo2C contribute to the measured surface area of these catalysts [16,24]. Results from high resolution TEM and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) are shown in Fig. 4S and elemental mapping of the Ni/Al, 1.1_2DMo-Ni/Al, and 1.0_βMo-Ni/Al catalysts are compared in Fig. 3. The Ni particles are clear in the HRTEM images (Fig. 4 S (a)). The Ni particle size distributions and the log-normal fit determined from multiple HRTEM images, are reported in Fig. 5 S. The average Ni particle size was 19.7 ± 4.3, 18.8 ± 9.0, and 26.1 ± 8.6 nm for the Ni/Al, 1.1_2DMo-Ni/Al, and 1.0_βMo-Ni/Al catalysts, respectively. Ni particle size estimated from the XRPD line-broadening analysis yielded 15.9, 14.7, and 21.7 nm, respectively. The layered structure of 2D-Mo2C was identified on the 1.1_2DMo-Ni/Al, as shown in Fig. 4. The space between the layers was estimated to be 1.5 nm somewhat larger than the < 1 nm reported for a 2D-Mo2C/SiO2 catalyst prepared in a similar way [14]. The difference in spacing could be due to the presence of Ni during the sonication step which resulted in higher expansion of the layers. The SAED images (Fig. 4 S (b)) show the presence of different Ni facets on the catalysts. The (111) and (220) facets were observed in all cases. For Ni/Al, an additional (110) facet was identified, while for both the 1.1_2DMo-Ni/Al, and 1.0_βMo-Ni/Al catalysts, a (022) facet, attributed to a NiMo phase, as previously confirmed by XRPD analysis for the 1.1_2DMo-Ni/Al and 2.6_2DMo-Ni/Al, was present. The elemental mapping of Ni and Mo is also shown in Fig. 3 (c, d, and e). The Ni and Mo overlap, indicative of a close interaction between the two elements, as reported in previous work [11]. The XPS Ni 2p scans for the Ni/Al, 1.1_2DMo-Ni/Al, and 1.0_βMo-Ni/Al catalysts are shown in Fig. 5 (a, b, and c), respectively. Analysis of the Ni 2p spectra was done assuming spin−orbit splitting assigned to Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 of 17.4 eV [31]. Results show the presence of Ni (0) and Ni (2+) on the surface of all the synthesized catalysts. For Ni/Al, the 2p3/2 characteristic peaks appeared at binding energies (BEs) of 852.0 and 855.5 eV. The Ni (2+) BE (855.5 eV) suggests the presence of NiO rather than NiAl2O4 (BE 855.9 – 857.0 eV). Also, a strong shake-up satellite of Ni 2p3/2 is shown at 861 eV. The peaks were shifted to higher BEs upon adding 2D-Mo2C or β-Mo2C to Ni/Al, such that for the 1.1_2DMo-Ni/Al the BEs were 852.4 and 855.8 eV, respectively and for the 1.0_βMo-Ni/Al BEs were 852.5 and 855.8 eV, respectively. The increase in Ni BEs is indicative of electron transfer from the less electronegative Ni to Mo (1.91 and 2.21 Pauling scale, respectively) and a BE of 856 eV has previously been assigned to Ni in Ni-Mo carbide [31]. This confirms a significant interaction between the Ni and Mo atoms for both the 1.1_2DMo-Ni/Al and 1.0_βMo-Ni/Al catalysts. Fig. 5 (d and e) compares the XPS spectra of Mo 3d for 1.1_2DMo-Ni/Al and 1.0_βMo-Ni/Al, respectively. Analysis of the Mo 3d spectra was done assuming spin−orbit splitting assigned to Mo 3d5/2 and Mo 3d3/2 of 3.1 eV [32]. Four Mo species were identified for both catalysts, including low concentrations (∼5 %) of zero valent Mo at a BE of 227.0 ± 0.5 eV, that is likely a result of the high temperature reduction in H2 done following synthesis. The peak at 228.4 ± 0.1 eV is assigned to Mo2C, while the two peaks at 231.5 ± 0.1 eV and 232.4 ± 0.1 eV are assigned to Mo-oxycarbide and oxide (Mo6+) species, respectively [32]. The XPS patterns were different for 2DMo-Ni/Al and βMo-Ni/Al. The former had ∼23 % of surface Mo species associated with Mo/Mo2C whereas on the β-Mo2C the value was ∼10 %. Surface Mo-oxide or oxycarbide species can act as a promoter in the DRM reaction [33], suppressing carbon deposition and increasing O mobility on the catalyst surface, leading to higher activity and stability of the catalyst [33]. The catalyst undergoes several cycles of reduction/oxidation during the reaction and as a result shows more stable performance under severe DRM reaction conditions. Similar cycles of reduction/oxidation for other types of two-dimensional catalyst (two-dimensional vanadium carbide) were observed in previous studies leading to an improved catalyst performance [15]. The Ni/Al and Mo/Al atom ratios obtained from EDX and XPS analyses are compared to the bulk ICP analysis in Table 2. The bulk Ni/Al and Mo/Al ratios among the three catalysts are very similar, indicating that the catalyst compositions were close to the targeted values despite the different methods of preparation. However, the near surface composition of the catalysts, as determined by EDX, show a higher Ni content and lower Mo content for the 1.0_βMo-Ni/Al catalyst compared to the 1.1_2DMo-Ni/Al catalyst, reflecting the fact that for the former, the Ni was added after the preparation of the β-Mo2C/γ-Al2O3 precursor. Despite this difference in EDX composition, the very near surface composition, as determined by XPS, remained quite similar among the three catalysts. Note that the differences between the quantities obtained by EDX and XPS are partly due to the larger sampling volume associated with EDX compared to XPS. The deviation is more severe in the case of the catalysts synthesized through the impregnation method. Finally, pulse chemisorption analysis showed 225.7 μmol/g and 306.1 μmol/g of CO chemisorbed on Ni/Al and 1.1_2DMo-Ni/Al surfaces, respectively. Assuming the CO adsorption occurs on Ni sites, we obtain Ni dispersions of 10.6 % and 13.7 %, respectively. Note that Ni particle size estimates made from the XRPD and TEM data are consistent with the estimated Ni dispersions. The higher amounts of CO adsorbed over the catalyst with 2D-Mo2C supports the presence of more active sites on the 1.1_2DMo-Ni/Al catalyst surface. 3.2 Catalyst activity and selectivity Fig. 6 compares the measured H2 and CO STYs from DRM at 800 °C, atmospheric pressure, GHSV of 13,500 mL (STP)/(h. gCat)), and CH4:CO2:Ar ratio of 1:1:0.25, over the Ni/Al catalyst and the 2DMo-Ni/Al catalysts with different loadings of 2D-Mo2C. The CH4 and CO2 conversions are reported in Table 1 S. To assess the catalyst performance, the H2 and CO STYs were considered particularly for kinetic modeling, rather than the CH4 and CO2 conversion rates, as the latter have inherently larger error associated with the difference between the inlet and outlet molar flows, particularly at lower temperatures and lower conversions. The data collected after 10 min and 180 minutes time-on-stream show that addition of 0.7 wt% 2D-Mo2C to Ni/Al increased the catalyst activity, with the highest activity obtained with 1.1 wt% 2D-Mo2C added to the Ni/Al. The H2 and CO STYs for this catalyst increased by 30 – 40 % compared to the Ni/Al (246.9 and 272.9 vs. 164.6 and 164.2 μmol/(s.gNi), respectively). However, increasing the 2D-Mo2C content to 2.6 wt%, resulted in a reduction in the H2 and CO STYs to 185.6 and 201.2 μmol/(s.gNi), respectively. The 1.1_2DMo-Ni/Al catalyst was also compared to a catalyst with the same composition but with 2D-Mo2C replaced with β-Mo2C, to highlight the effect of the two-dimensional structure on the catalyst activity. The catalytic activities compared in Fig. 6 show that the 1.0_βMo-Ni/Al activity was even lower than that of the Ni/Al catalyst with H2 and CO STYs of 116.9 and 124.4 μmol/(s.gNi), respectively. Although previous studies have reported significant DRM activity over β-Mo2C [34–37], the low amount of β-Mo2C (1.0 wt%) used in the present study, likely means that the Ni dominates the observed performance of the 1.0_βMo-Ni/Al catalyst and that some Ni is covered by less active β-Mo2C [38]. The product gas H2/CO molar ratio for all the catalysts is also presented in Fig. 6, with ratios of 0.91–1.08 obtained for all catalysts at the operating conditions. The H2/CO ratios obtained in the present study were significantly higher than those reported previously over two-dimensional catalysts. For example, Kurlov et al. [14] reported a H2/CO product ratio of 0.6 over 2D-Mo2COx/SiO2. Similar values were reported over a 2D-V2C catalyst (0.7) [15] and a Ni-Mo2C catalyst (0.6) [12]. The STY data measured after 10 and 180 minutes time-on-stream (Fig. 6) indicate that the presence of 2D-Mo2C reduced the extent of catalyst deactivation compared to Ni/Al, likely because of the presence of interactions between Ni and Mo, identified from the EDX mapping images (see Fig. 3) and XPS results (see Fig. 5). Similar interactions between Ni and Mo reported in previous studies, also resulted in improved catalyst stability [11,39]. Hence the stability of Ni/Al and 1.1_2DMo-Ni/Al was further evaluated at the same conditions (T = 800 °C and GHSV = 13500 mL(STP)/(h. gCat)) over a 24 h time-on-stream period. The results ( Fig. 7) showed that the 1.1_2DMo-Ni/Al catalyst was notably more stable than the Ni/Al catalyst, such that reductions of only 5 and 6 % in the initial H2 and CO STYs were observed over the promoted catalyst, compared to reductions of 23 and 18 %, respectively, observed over the Ni/Al catalyst. The higher resistance toward coke deposition could be because of the role of 2D-Mo2C in the dissociation of CO2 and the subsequent production of free oxygen that can remove deposited carbon from the surface [40]. On the other hand, Mo2C is prone to oxidation at atmospheric pressure in the presence of CO2 and the resulting Mo-oxide has no activity toward DRM [12]. Therefore, the presence of Ni and its high affinity for coke formation may also contribute to stabilizing the 2D-Mo2C, thereby maintaining activity for the reaction. As a result, the catalyst benefitted from the presence of both Ni and 2D-Mo2C and the close interaction between both, as deduced from the characterization data. To obtain further insight into the stability of the two catalysts (Ni/Al and 1.1_2DMo-Ni/Al), the amount of carbon deposited on the catalysts after 24 h time-on-stream was measured by thermogravimetric analysis in air. To determine the possible weight change due to the oxidation of Ni, the analysis was also done on the fresh, calcined and reduced Ni/Al. Fig. 8 reports a first weight loss of 3.5 % over the two used catalysts compared to 2.5 % over the fresh catalyst at temperatures lower than 400 °C. This initial weight loss is due to the presence of water, volatile compounds, or other types of coke precursors. Subsequently, there is a slight increase in weight as temperature increased to 500 °C, due to the oxidation of the Ni. The fresh Ni/Al had the highest increase in weight (3.1 %), close to the theoretical increase of 3.5 % expected if the Ni were completely oxidized to NiO. The increase was 1.5 % for the used 2DMo-Ni/Al and 0.8 % for used Ni/Al. The higher oxidation over the promoted catalyst could be due to the lower amount of coke that is present on this catalyst. The second and the most significant weight loss occurred from 500 to 700 °C and was only observed over the used catalysts, indicating the presence of hard coke. More than 1.5 times higher weight loss was observed for the used Ni/Al catalyst compared to the used 2DMo-Ni/Al catalyst (21.2 % vs. 13.6 %). Clearly there is a much more severe carbon deposition on the Ni/Al catalyst compared to the 2DMo-Ni/Al catalyst over the 24 h reaction period. The DTG graph shown in Fig. 6 S indicates that for the 2DMo-Ni/Al catalyst the high temperature weight loss occurs in two distinct steps suggesting the presence of two different active components (Ni and 2D-Mo2C) on the surface. The results reported in Figs. 6–8 clearly demonstrate the enhancements in both the activity and stability of Ni/Al with the addition of 2D-Mo2C. Previously, Kurlov et al. reported that a 2D morphology was critical for high stability and catalytic activity of a 2D-Mo2C/SiO2 catalyst. These authors demonstrated that 2D-Mo2COx, with a surface oxygen coverage of 0.67 of a monolayer and a Mo oxidation state of ca. +4, was optimal for catalytic performance. The DRM proceeded on Mo sites of the oxycarbide nanosheet with methane activation the rate-limiting step. CH4 and CO2 conversion rates, estimated from their data at 730 °C, are 15 and 29 µmol/(g cat.s), respectively, and are of similar magnitude to those obtained in the present study (25 and 28 µmol/(g cat.s) at 800°C). In the present study the Ni promotes the dissociation of methane resulting in significantly higher H2/CO ratios in the product (∼1) compared to the H2/CO product ratio of 0.6 reported by Kurlov et al. [14]. Furthermore, the presence of a surface Ni-Mo-oxycarbide identified by XPS in the present study, is consistent with increased CO2 activation that increases surface oxygen, as proposed by Kurlov et al. [14]. The higher surface O reduces carbon build up on the catalyst surface and results in improved catalyst stability, compared to the Ni/Al catalyst. The importance of oxy-carbide surface species for DRM has also been demonstrated by Thakur et al. [15] in which a 2D vanadium carbide MXene (m-V2CTx) yielded a robust oxy-carbide (V2O3-V8C7/m-V2CTx) catalyst for DRM with high activity and stability. At 800 °C, CH4 and CO2 conversion rates were 18.6 and 19.5 μmol/(g Cat.s), respectively, of similar magnitude to the values obtained in the present study over the 2D-Mo2C/Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. Thakur et al. [15] also demonstrated that the V2O3−V8C7/m-V2CTx catalyst undergoes a redox (oxidation-carburization) mechanism that results in attractive reactivity, selectivity (H2/CO ratio close to unity), and stability. The interactions between 2D-Mo2C and Ni, confirmed by the presence of NixMoy structures shown in the XRD pattern and the (022) facets observed in SAED, result in higher resistance to coke formation and oxidation of the catalyst, making it more active and stable compared to the Ni/Al catalyst. Such interactions are also supported by the co-location of Ni and Mo observed in the TEM/EDX images and the XPS analysis, showing electron transfer from Ni to Mo and the presence of Ni-Mo-oxycarbide surface species. Similar observations were reported by Shi et al. [12] for DRM over a Ni-Mo2C catalyst. These authors showed that having both Ni and Mo2C with an optimum molar ratio of 1:2, resulted in an established balance in an oxidation-recarburization process which preserved Ni from coke deposition in the presence of CH4 and Mo2C from oxidation in the presence of CO2, resulting in higher stability and activity of the catalyst. 3.3 Kinetics The kinetics of the DRM reaction over the Ni/Al and the 1.1_2DMo-Ni/Al catalysts have been investigated in the temperature range 650–850 °C with CH4 and CO2 partial pressures of 20 – 110 kPa while the GHSV remained constant at 60,000 mL (STP)/(h. gCat) using Ar as a balance gas. A total of 36 experimental data points were collected under integral conditions over each catalyst, with CH4 and CO2 conversions between 5 % and 30 %. Figs. 9 and 10 report the effect of CH4 and CO2 partial pressures on the H2 and CO STYs over Ni/Al and 1.1_2DMo-Ni/Al, respectively. The H2 and CO STYs were significantly higher over the 1.1_2DMo-Ni/Al catalyst compared to the Ni/Al catalyst. Furthermore, increasing CH4 partial pressure increased both H2 and CO STYs over both catalysts (see Figs. 9 and 10), however, the increase was more significant over the promoted catalyst at higher temperature (800 °C). Increasing CO2 partial pressure also increased the CO STYs but did not significantly influence the H2 STYs over the two catalysts, suggesting that H2 was generated through a pathway involving CH4 alone. These findings align with similar observations reported elsewhere [41]. Since the measured data of Figs. 9 and 10 show an increase in STYs with increase in CH4 partial pressure and (to a lesser extent) with CO2 partial pressure, simplified power-law kinetic models (Eq. 6 and Eq. 7) were used to describe the H2 and CO production rates. (6) r H 2 = 2 k i 0 e − E ai R × ( 1 T − 1 T ave ) P CH 4 a P CO 2 b (7) r CO = 2 k j 0 e − E aj R × ( 1 T − 1 T ave ) P CH 4 c P CO 2 d where the production rate of H2 or CO, (r i ) is in mol/(s. gNi), partial pressures (p j) are in kPa, R is the universal gas constant (8.314 J/(mol. K)), T and T avg are in K where T avg is the average of the temperatures that have been used for each catalyst (T avg=1056.5 K for the Ni/Al catalyst and T avg=989.8 K for the1.1_2DMo-Ni/Al catalyst). (E a ) is the apparent activation energy in J/mol, k i 0 is pre-exponential factor in (mol/(s. gNi))(kPa)˗(m+n), (m) and (n) are the order of reaction with respect to CH4 and CO2. To obtain estimates of the model parameters using the measured STYs, the design equation for an isothermal plug-flow reactor (Eq. 8) was integrated numerically using a Runge-Kutta algorithm to obtain the STYs at the reactor exit (Eq. 9): (8) d F H 2 dW = r H 2 and d F CO dW = r CO (9) STY H 2 = F H 2 W and STY CO = F CO W The unknown kinetic parameters were determined using a Marquardt–Levenberg optimization procedure, by minimizing the objective function (Eq. 10): (10) S = ∑ ( STY CO M − STY CO C ) 2 + ( STY H 2 M − STY H 2 C ) 2 where the superscript M and C refer to the measured and the model calculated values, respectively. A statistically significant fit was obtained based on the proposed power-law models (Eqs. 6 and 7) with the estimated kinetic parameters reported in Table 3 and the fit of the model shown in Figs. 9 and 10. Note that for both catalysts the CO2 partial pressure exponent (b) in Eq. 6 was not statistically significant and so was set to zero. As shown in Figs. 9 and 10, the simplified power law model can adequately describe the experimental data. Table 3 also reports the turn-over-frequency (TOF) obtained over the two catalysts and shows that the TOF over the 1.1_2DMo-Ni/Al catalyst was 2.5×’s greater than the Ni/Al catalyst at 800°C. The data of Figs. 9 and 10 also show that for both catalysts the CO STY was greater than the H2 STY. However, if DRM is the only reaction occurring on the catalysts, stoichiometry requires the CO and H2 STYs to be equal. Several side reactions can occur at DRM conditions [42]. In the present study, analysis of the products by gas chromatography showed no evidence of higher (C2+) hydrocarbons or alcohols production while the amount of H2O produced over the catalysts at all conditions was found to be insignificant. Hence, the thermodynamically feasible reactions reduced to CH4 decomposition (MD), the reverse Boudouard reaction (RBD), and the reverse water-gas shift reaction (RWGS) as listed in Table 4 [42]. Fig. 7 S shows the dependency of the equilibrium constant of the reactions as a function of temperature, estimated by Aspen Plus V11 [44]. As shown in Fig. 7 S, the DRM, MD, and RBD reactions are thermodynamically feasible over the entire temperature range of the present study, while the RWGS can occur mostly at higher temperatures. Shi et al. proposed that the DRM reaction over a Ni-Mo2C catalyst occurs by CH4 activation on Ni sites and CO2 activation on Mo2C sites [12], as indicated by the following reaction steps: CH 4 → C * + 2 H 2 CO 2 → CO + O * C * + O * → CO The proposed reaction steps are kinetically consistent with the CH4 decomposition (first step) and the reverse Boudouard reaction (CO2 activation) occurring over the two different sites (Ni and Mo2C) of the catalyst, respectively. Since the H2 production rate is independent of the CO2 partial pressure (Figs. 9 (c) and 10 (c)) and not equal to the CO production rate, it is plausible that H2 and CO are produced through the MD and RBD reactions, respectively. The power law kinetics reported in Table 3 are consistent with this proposal if one assumes that MD (i.e. H2 production) is dependent only on the CH4 partial pressure and that the surface concentration of C* and O* are dependent on the partial pressures of CH4 and CO2, respectively. Note also that the simultaneous occurrence of the RWGS and DRM could also result in a higher CO STY compared to the H2 STY and is another possible DRM reaction pathway that can explain the observed trends in Figs. 9 and 10. With increased CO2 partial pressure, both the DRM and RWGS rate would be expected to increase, with the net effect on the H2 production rate being minimal, particularly at higher partial pressures of CO2 [41,44,45]. However, application of power law kinetic equations to the RWGS and DRM reactions of the present study did not result in meaningful kinetic parameter estimates and provided a lower quality fit of the data. Hence, we conclude that for the Ni/Al and 1.1_2DMo-Ni/Al catalysts of the present study, the DRM reaction kinetics are better described by the MD and RBD reactions. The estimated activation energies for H2 (produced via MD) and CO (produced via the RBD reaction) reported in Table 3 are among the lowest activation energies that have been reported for DRM. Although the rate of reaction over 1.1_2DMo-Ni/Al was significantly higher than that over the Ni/Al catalyst, the obtained activation energies for the promoted catalyst (H2 - 64.69 ± 4.23 kJ/mol and CO - 79.60 ± 3.88 kJ/mol) were higher than the values obtained over the Ni/Al catalyst (H2 - 36.23 ± 3.28 kJ/mol and CO - 50.76 ± 3.12 kJ/mol). The high activation energy over the 1.1_2DMo-Ni/Al catalyst could also be attributed to the fact that transition metal carbide catalysts, such as Mo2C, typically require higher reaction temperatures compared to Ni to become activated for the DRM reaction [46,47]. The pre-exponential factors obtained over the 1.1_2DMo-Ni/Al catalyst for both H2 and CO were much higher than the Ni/Al catalyst, suggesting the presence of a kinetic compensation effect. The kinetic compensation effect shows that the lower activation energy requires the formation of a highly organized system meaning lower entropy and thus the lower pre-exponential factor, which seems to be the case for the unpromoted catalyst. The H2 and CO rate dependency on CH4 partial pressure was almost the same over both the Ni/Al and the 1.1_2DMo-Ni/Al catalysts (a = 0.79 ± 0.07 and 0.73 ± 0.09; c = 0.58 ± 0.06 and 0.58 ± 0.08, respectively). However, the CO rate dependency on CO2 partial pressure was higher over the 1.1_2DMo-Ni/Al catalyst compared to the Ni/Al catalyst (0.53 ± 0.07 vs. 0.44 ± 0.06). The CO2 partial pressure played a key role in the performance of the promoted catalyst. The higher CO2 partial pressure exponent for the 1.1_2DMo-Ni/Al catalyst reflects the high affinity of the 2D-Mo2C for any type of oxidant such as CO2 [38] and is consistent with the observations of Shi et al. [12] that CH4 decomposition likely occurs over Ni sites and CO2 activation occurs over both Ni and 2D-Mo2C active sites [38,46,48,49]. 4 Conclusion Two-dimensional Mo2C was successfully synthesized from Mo2Ga2C and used to prepare a series of 2D-Mo2C-Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts for the dry reforming of methane. The best catalyst with 1.1 wt% 2D-Mo2C showed about 40 % higher activity compared to Ni/γ-Al2O3 alone. This catalyst also had improved stability with only ∼5 % reduction in the initial activity after 24 h time-on-stream, while the reduction in the initial activity of the Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was about 20 %. The 2D-Mo2C-Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst also showed superior activity compared to the catalyst with same loading of β-Mo2C. Surface (XPS) and bulk (XRD, TEM) characterization of the 2D-Mo2C-Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst confirmed an interaction between the Ni and 2D-Mo2C that resulted in improved activity and higher resistance toward coke formation. The H2 and CO STYs were well described by power law kinetics consistent with the occurrence of the MD and RBD reactions, rather than the direct DRM reaction, with the MD and RBD occurring on the Ni and 2D-Mo2C sites, respectively. The two reactions may also occur over the Ni sites of the unpromoted catalyst with lower overall rate of reaction. CRediT authorship contribution statement Kevin J. coredata.dc:description: The impact of two-dimensional Mo2C (2D-Mo2C) on the activity and stability of a Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst for the dry reforming of methane (DRM) is reported. 1.1 wt% 2D-Mo2C added to 13 wt% Ni/γ-Al2O3 increased activity by ∼40 %. Characterization results showed an interaction between 2D-Mo2C and Ni that resulted in the formation of a NixMoy bulk phase (XRD) and Ni-Mo-oxycarbide surface species (XPS). The presence of 2D-Mo2C also improved the stability of the catalyst compared to Ni/γ-Al2O3 by reducing coke deposition. H2 space-time-yields (STYs) were independent of CO2 partial pressure and were lower than the CO STYs. Power law kinetic models were consistent with a DRM reaction pathway via CH4 decomposition (MD) and the reverse Boudouard (RBD) reactions.
